title: getting started with autoclust
text: Evaluate clustering using autoantibody positivities.simulate synthetic dataset 500 samples, 20 antibodies 4 theoretical clusters. need read data excel file example can run:clinical_data_df <- read.xlsx("/path///data") replacing "/path///data" path data located computer.
code: # DO NOT DO THIS - This is only to show how to cluster, but this will generate synthetic data. clinical_data_df <- generate_synthetic_clusters(n_samples = 100, n_vars = 10, n_clusters = 3, n_batches = 1, data_type = "binary")  # Assign column names to "Antibody" and 1 to number of antibodies colnames(clinical_data_df) <- paste0("antibody", seq(1,length(colnames(clinical_data_df))))  # Explore dataset head(clinical_data_df) ##         antibody1 antibody2 antibody3 antibody4 antibody5 antibody6 antibody7 ## sample1         1         0         1         0         1         1         1 ## sample2         1         0         1         0         1         1         1 ## sample3         1         0         1         0         1         1         1 ## sample4         1         0         1         0         0         1         1 ## sample5         1         0         1         0         1         1         1 ## sample6         1         0         1         0         1         1         1 ##         antibody8 antibody9 antibody10 antibody11 antibody12 ## sample1         0         1          0          1          1 ## sample2         0         1          0          1          1 ## sample3         0         1          0          1          1 ## sample4         0         1          0          1          1 ## sample5         0         1          0          1          1 ## sample6         0         1          0          1          1 # Establish a directory where to save your results output_data_dir <- "." # This will save the results in the current working directory. You can change it for whatever you want.

title: getting started with autoclust
text: One can see possible parameters function running: /home/runner/work/_temp/Library/autoclust/help/cluster_eval
code: # Run cluster evaluation n_boots <- 10 # How many iterations? n_dim <- 10 # Until how many clusters to calculate cluster_evaluation_autoantibodies <- cluster_eval(x = clinical_data_df, ndim = n_dim, distance = "gower",                                                             clust_method = "pam", save_plot = TRUE, data_type = "continous",                                                              boot_runs = n_boots, plots_suffix = "clust_positv_pam_gower",                                                             plots_dir = output_data_dir)

title: getting started with autoclust
text: Show cluster stability plots.

title: getting started with autoclust
text: Silhouette scores per patient per cluster. .e. well separated clusters, much overlap (separate) . data point (patient case), intra-cluster distance (.e. close point points within cluster) nearest-cluster distance (.e. far data point points nearest neighboring cluster) calculated. individual silhouette scores represented first 10 plots, average represented last plot.
code: # Show silhouette plots cowplot::plot_grid(plotlist = lapply(cluster_evaluation_autoantibodies$silhouette_plots, function(x) x), ncol = 2) + theme_bw()

title: getting started with autoclust
text: Bootstrap stability represented mean jaccard index, .e. similar clusters within several iterations carried . Mean jaccard score cluster displayed.
code: # Show jaccard index plots cowplot::plot_grid(plotlist = lapply(cluster_evaluation_autoantibodies$bootstrap, function(x) x$plot + theme_bw()))

title: getting started with autoclust
text: Make line plot using cluster assignments “regular” clustering using specified distance matrix clustering algorithm, consensus class, uses boostrap information assign patients cluster likely belong based n_boots number iterations.
code: # Add group information to your clinical df clinical_data_wcluster_df <- clinical_data_df %>%   mutate(gower_pam_positiv_2k = as.factor(cluster_evaluation_autoantibodies$fit$`2`$clustering),         gower_pam_positiv_3k = as.factor(cluster_evaluation_autoantibodies$fit$`3`$clustering),         gower_pam_positiv_2k_consensus = as.factor(cluster_evaluation_autoantibodies$consensus_clustering$result[[2]]$consensusClass),         gower_pam_positiv_3k_consensus = cluster_evaluation_autoantibodies$consensus_clustering$result[[3]]$consensusClass) # For pam_gower clustering  aa_colnames <- colnames(clinical_data_df) # Change this to the name of your antibodies  make_aa_lineplot(x = clinical_data_wcluster_df, aa_colnames = aa_colnames,    subgroup_column = "gower_pam_positiv_2k") make_aa_lineplot(x = clinical_data_wcluster_df, aa_colnames = aa_colnames,    subgroup_column = "gower_pam_positiv_3k") make_aa_lineplot(x = clinical_data_wcluster_df, aa_colnames = aa_colnames,    subgroup_column = "gower_pam_positiv_2k_consensus") make_aa_lineplot(x = clinical_data_wcluster_df, aa_colnames = aa_colnames,    subgroup_column = "gower_pam_positiv_3k_consensus")

title: getting started with autoclust
text: part, also make 3 synthetic columns hypothetical binary variables, clinical dataset information, replace section name columns.
code: # DO NOT DO THIS - make hypothetical clinical manifestations and sex clinical_manifestations <- generate_synthetic_clusters(n_samples = 100, n_vars = 4, n_clusters = 3, n_batches = 1, data_type = "binary") %>% select(var1, var2, var3, var4)  colnames(clinical_manifestations) <- c("Arthritis", "MI", "IBD", "sex")  clinical_data_wcluster_df <- merge(clinical_data_wcluster_df, clinical_manifestations)  # Define clinical manifestations to test for association clinical_manifestations <- c("Arthritis", "MI", "IBD") # replace with your manifestations names  associations_positiv_2k_clust <- run_associations(clinical_data_df = clinical_data_wcluster_df,    clinical_data_cols = clinical_manifestations,    predictor_var_colname = "gower_pam_positiv_2k",    adjust_by = "sex", filter_sig_OR = FALSE, # Set to true if you want to keep only significant results in the forest plot   plot = TRUE, ntop = 10)

title: getting started with autoclust
text: Show forest plots top associations. calling names(associations_positiv_2k_clust) can see output analysis contains: models anova summarized_results df forest_plot  ** interpret ?** results plots show “clinical manifestation - cluster - clustering_variable”, clinical manifestation corresponds outcome variable, cluster corresponds cluster membership one-v.s.-manner. clinical manifestation corresponds dependent variable (variable modelled), cluster membership corresponds independent (predictor) variable. clinical manifestation case model form:clinical manifestation ~ gower_pam_positiv_2k + sex
code: names(associations_positiv_2k_clust) # Here you can see the information this variable contains. ## [1] "models"             "anova"              "summarized_results" ## [4] "df"                 "forest_plot" #associations_positiv_2k_clust$anova # ANOVA results associations_positiv_2k_clust$forest_plot # forest plots

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ana Cristina Gonzalez. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Gonzalez (2025). autoclust: Clustering using autoantibodies association clinical variables.. R package version 1.0.0.
code: @Manual{,   title = {autoclust: Clustering using autoantibodies and association to clinical variables.},   author = {Ana Cristina Gonzalez},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 1.0.0}, }

what: Clustering using autoantibodies and association to clinical variables.
title: Clustering using autoantibodies and association to clinical variables.
text: Automated clustering association testing patient stratification using antibody, proteomic, clinical data.

title: Clustering using autoantibodies and association to clinical variables.
text: autoclust R package designed unsupervised clustering association testing heterogeneous biomedical datasets. supports: - Clustering Gower distance, PAM, algorithms - Cluster evaluation via silhouette, bootstrap stability, consensus metrics - Association testing clinical variables using frequentist Bayesian logistic regression - Visualization tools cluster separation, stability, clinical effect sizes Originally developed patient stratification Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) cohorts, autoclust applicable multi-feature biomedical dataset mixed data types.

title: Clustering using autoantibodies and association to clinical variables.
text: can install latest development version directly GitHub:
code: # Install devtools if you haven't already install.packages("devtools")  # Install autoclust devtools::install_github("Anacristina0914/autoclust")

title: Retrieve Colors for ACR Subgroups and Other Variables — acr_subgroups_paper_colors
text: sg1_var_name Name subgroup 1 (default: "1") sg2_var_name Name subgroup 2 (default: "2") sg3_var_name Name subgroup 3 (default: "3") sg4_var_name Name subgroup 4 (default: "4") fem_var_name Name Female (default: "Female") mas_var_name Name Male (default: "Male") case_var_name Name Cases (default: "case") control_var_name Name Controls (default: "control")

what: Evaluate Clustering Performance Using Mixed Data — cluster_eval
title: Evaluate Clustering Performance Using Mixed Data — cluster_eval
text: Performs comprehensive evaluation clustering performance using silhouette scores, consensus clustering, bootstrap stability. Supports continuous binary data multiple clustering algorithms.

title: Evaluate Clustering Performance Using Mixed Data — cluster_eval
code: cluster_eval(   x,   ndim = 10,   clust_method = "pam",   distance = "auto",   data_type = "binary",   sillplot_dot_size = 6,   save_plot = TRUE,   nclust = NA,   interactive = FALSE,   boot_runs = 100,   seed = 123,   compute_consensus = TRUE,   compute_jaccard = TRUE,   consensus_runs = 100,   stand = FALSE,   plots_suffix = paste0(distance, "_", clust_method),   plots_dir = getwd() )

title: Evaluate Clustering Performance Using Mixed Data — cluster_eval
text: x data frame matrix observations (rows = samples, columns = features). Can include binary continuous variables. ndim Integer. Maximum number clusters evaluate (default = 10). clust_method Clustering method use. Options "pam", "kmeans", "clara", "hclust". distance Distance metric use. "auto" (default) uses "gower" binary data "euclidean" continuous. options can passed cluster::daisy(), e.g., "manhattan", "gower", "euclidean". data_type Type data: "binary" "continuous". Used distance = "auto". sillplot_dot_size Size dots silhouette width plot (default = 6). save_plot Logical. Save plots disk? (default = TRUE). nclust Optional. Number clusters use evaluation. NA, selects best k based silhouette score (default = NA). interactive Logical. TRUE, returns interactive silhouette plots using plotly (default = FALSE). boot_runs Integer. Number bootstrap resamples Jaccard stability index (default = 100). seed Random seed reproducibility (default = 123). compute_consensus Logical. TRUE, performs consensus clustering (default = TRUE). compute_jaccard Logical. TRUE, computes bootstrap-based Jaccard index cluster stability (default = TRUE). consensus_runs Integer. Number resamples consensus clustering (default = 100). plots_suffix Character string added filenames saving plots (default = paste0(distance, "_", clust_method)). plots_dir Directory plots saved (default = current working directory).

title: Evaluate Clustering Performance Using Mixed Data — cluster_eval
text: list following elements: silhouette_plots list silhouette plots evaluated number clusters, summary plot. fit Fitted clustering objects k. bootstrap Bootstrap cluster stability results k (compute_jaccard = TRUE). consensus_clustering ConsensusClusterPlus results ICL scores (compute_consensus = TRUE). best_nclust optimal number clusters based average silhouette width. method clustering method used.

title: Evaluate Clustering Performance Using Mixed Data — cluster_eval
text: function streamlines evaluation clustering strategies binary continuous datasets using silhouette scores, consensus clustering, cluster stability (via bootstrapped Jaccard index). Useful benchmarking clustering algorithms selecting optimal k.

title: Evaluate Clustering Performance Using Mixed Data — cluster_eval
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data <- generate_synthetic_mixed_data(n_samples = 300, n_clusters = 3, n_continuous = 4, n_binary = 4) x <- data[, -ncol(data)]  # remove true cluster labels result <- cluster_eval(x, data_type = "binary", clust_method = "pam", distance = "gower") result$best_nclust } # }

title: Compute Bootstrap Clustering Stability — compute_bootstrap_stability
text: Computes clustering stability using bootstrap resampling Jaccard similarity based clusterboot function. Returns bootstrap mean Jaccard index cluster bar plot summarizing cluster stability.

title: Compute Bootstrap Clustering Stability — compute_bootstrap_stability
code: compute_bootstrap_stability(   x,   nclust,   plot_dir,   plots_suffix,   B = 100,   bootmethod = "boot",   seed = 123,   clustermethod = NULL,   diss = TRUE,   theme = theme_minimal(),   save_plot = FALSE )

title: Compute Bootstrap Clustering Stability — compute_bootstrap_stability
text: x dissimilarity matrix (diss = TRUE) data matrix (diss = FALSE). nclust Integer. number clusters evaluate. plot_dir Character. Directory plots saved. plots_suffix Character. Suffix used naming output plots. B Integer. Number bootstrap resampling iterations. Default 100. bootmethod Character. Resampling method. Typically "boot" "subset". seed Integer. Random seed reproducibility. Default 123. clustermethod clustering function format expected fpc::clusterboot. diss Logical. Whether x dissimilarity matrix (TRUE) data matrix (FALSE). theme ggplot2 theme object customize stability plot. Default theme_minimal(). save_plot Logical. Whether save plot JPEG file. Default FALSE.

title: Compute Bootstrap Clustering Stability — compute_bootstrap_stability
text: list following components: stats full result fpc::clusterboot. plot ggplot2 object showing mean Jaccard similarity per cluster. save_plot = TRUE, plot also saved JPEG file specified directory.

what: Compute and Visualize a Dissimilarity Matrix — compute_dissimilarity_matrix
title: Compute and Visualize a Dissimilarity Matrix — compute_dissimilarity_matrix
text: Computes dissimilarity matrix using daisy function optionally visualizes using heatmap.

title: Compute and Visualize a Dissimilarity Matrix — compute_dissimilarity_matrix
code: compute_dissimilarity_matrix(   x,   metric = c("euclidean", "manhattan", "gower"),   stand = FALSE,   return_dis = FALSE,   plot_dissim = TRUE,   heatmap_title = paste0(metric, " Dissimilarity Matrix"),   heatmap_axis_text_size = 4,   plot_title_size = 20,   save_plots = FALSE,   plot_outpath = "." )

title: Compute and Visualize a Dissimilarity Matrix — compute_dissimilarity_matrix
text: x data matrix data frame. metric Character. Dissimilarity metric use: "euclidean", "manhattan", "gower". stand Logical. Whether standardize variables (used non-Gower metrics). return_dis Logical. TRUE, returns dissimilarity object; else returns matrix. plot_dissim Logical. Whether generate dissimilarity heatmap. heatmap_title Character. Title heatmap plot. heatmap_axis_text_size Numeric. Axis text size heatmap. plot_title_size Numeric. Plot title font size. save_plots Logical. TRUE, saves heatmap. plot_outpath Character. Directory plot saved.

title: Compute and Visualize a Dissimilarity Matrix — compute_dissimilarity_matrix
text: list containing: dissimilarity_matrix Either dissimilarity object matrix, depending return_dis. heatmap_plot (Optional) ggplot2 heatmap plot dissimilarity matrix.

what: Extract Autoantibody and Subgroup Columns — extract_aa_columns
title: Extract Autoantibody and Subgroup Columns — extract_aa_columns
text: Extracts subset data frame containing specified autoantibody columns subgroup column. Supports input either column names column positions.

title: Extract Autoantibody and Subgroup Columns — extract_aa_columns
code: extract_aa_columns(data_frame, autoantibody_columns, subgroup_column)

title: Extract Autoantibody and Subgroup Columns — extract_aa_columns
text: data_frame data frame containing autoantibody measurements subgroup information. autoantibody_columns character vector column names integer vector column positions corresponding autoantibody variables extract. subgroup_column character string integer indicating subgroup column extract.

title: Extract Autoantibody and Subgroup Columns — extract_aa_columns
text: list three elements: aa_data data frame containing selected autoantibody columns subgroup column. antibody_cols column positions (indices) selected autoantibody columns. subgroup_col_number column position (index) selected subgroup column.

title: Extract Autoantibody and Subgroup Columns — extract_aa_columns
text: function checks type autoantibody_columns subgroup_column: character, matches column names. integer, uses directly positions. input neither character integer, error thrown.

title: Extract Autoantibody and Subgroup Columns — extract_aa_columns
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example usage df <- your_data_frame autoantibody_vars <- c("anti-dsDNA", "anti-Sm", "anti-RNP") result <- extract_aa_columns(df, autoantibody_columns = autoantibody_vars, subgroup_column = "Clustering") head(result[[1]]) # View extracted data } # }

title: Generate Synthetic Clustered Datasets — generate_synthetic_clusters
text: Simulates clustered datasets (binary continuous) optional batch effects. Useful testing benchmarking clustering algorithms.

title: Generate Synthetic Clustered Datasets — generate_synthetic_clusters
code: generate_synthetic_clusters(   n_samples = 100,   n_vars = 10,   n_clusters = 3,   n_batches = 1,   data_type = c("binary", "continuous"),   cluster_sep = 1,   flip_prob = 0.05,   random_state = NULL )

title: Generate Synthetic Clustered Datasets — generate_synthetic_clusters
text: n_samples Integer. Total number samples. n_vars Integer. Number features (variables). n_clusters Integer. Number clusters generate. n_batches Integer. Number batches simulate. 0, batch effect added. data_type Character. Either "continuous" "binary". cluster_sep Numeric. Controls separation cluster centers. df Optional reference dataframe. provided, sampling perturbation based data. noise_sd Numeric. Standard deviation Gaussian noise (continuous data). noise_prob Numeric. Probability flipping bits (binary data). batch_effect_strength Numeric. Controls strength batch effect. seed Integer. Random seed reproducibility.

title: Generate Synthetic Clustered Datasets — generate_synthetic_clusters
text: data frame synthetic data Cluster column. n_batches > 0, includes Batch column.

title: Retrieves KI Colors — ki_colors

what: Make line plot for autoantibody frequencies per subgroup — make_aa_lineplot
title: Make line plot for autoantibody frequencies per subgroup — make_aa_lineplot
text: Make line plot autoantibody frequencies per subgroup

title: Make line plot for autoantibody frequencies per subgroup — make_aa_lineplot
code: make_aa_lineplot(   x,   aa_colnames,   subgroup_column,   subgroup_colors = distinctColorPalette(k = length(unique(x %>%     pull(subgroup_column)))),   line_width = 1.5,   geom_point = 2,   plot_theme = autoclust::theme_clustering(text_size = 8, plot_title_size = 18),   ... )

title: Make line plot for autoantibody frequencies per subgroup — make_aa_lineplot
text: x Data frame autoantibody subgroup columns. aa_colnames Character vector antibody columns. subgroup_column Name column defining subgroups. subgroup_colors Optional custom colors. line_width Line thickness. geom_point Point size. plot_theme Plot theme (default: autoclust theme). ... Additional arguments passed ggplot2::labs.

title: Make line plot for autoantibody frequencies per subgroup — make_aa_lineplot
text: ggplot2 object showing antibody frequencies.

what: Create a Forest Plot of Association Results — make_forest_plot
title: Create a Forest Plot of Association Results — make_forest_plot
text: function generates publication-ready forest plot summarizing odds ratios (ORs), 95% confidence intervals, p-values (adjusted p-values) association analyses, produced run_associations(). filters, ranks, visualizes significant associations across clinical manifestations predictor variables.

title: Create a Forest Plot of Association Results — make_forest_plot
code: make_forest_plot(   results_df,   clinical_manifestation,   predictor_var_colname,   adjust_vars,   clinical_manifestation_colname = "clinical_manifestation",   ntop = NULL,   adjust_p = adjust_p,   p_adj_method = p_adj_method,   pt.size = pt.size,   y.axis.text.size,   x.axis.text.size,   or.label.size,   plot_title = "",   name_mapping = NULL,   add_xylabs = FALSE,   filter_sig_OR = TRUE )

title: Create a Forest Plot of Association Results — make_forest_plot
text: results_df data frame containing association results, including columns , 2.5 %, 97.5 %, p-values (e.g., Pr\>|z\|), optionally adjusted p-values (adj_p). clinical_manifestation Character vector clinical manifestation names include plot. predictor_var_colname Character string specifying column name predictor variable. adjust_vars Character vector string adjustment variables used model (e.g., "Age_dx + sex"). Used remove adjusted terms plotted results. clinical_manifestation_colname Character string indicating column name results_df corresponding clinical manifestation variable (default: "clinical_manifestation"). ntop Integer specifying number top associations () include plot (default: NULL, plots ). adjust_p Logical indicating whether adjusted p-values (adj_p) used coloring points (default: inherits calling environment). p_adj_method Character string specifying p-value adjustment method (default: inherits calling environment). pt.size Numeric value controlling point size forest plot. y.axis.text.size Numeric value specifying text size y-axis labels. x.axis.text.size Numeric value specifying text size x-axis labels. .label.size Numeric value controlling size odds ratio text labels. plot_title Character string specifying plot title (default: ""). name_mapping Optional named vector list mapping variable names human-readable labels. add_xylabs Logical; TRUE, adds axis labels title plot (default: FALSE). filter_sig_OR Logical; TRUE, filters results include significant ORs (.e., 95% CI cross 1) (default: TRUE).

title: Create a Forest Plot of Association Results — make_forest_plot
text: ggplot2 object representing forest plot, ready customization saving.

title: Create a Forest Plot of Association Results — make_forest_plot
text: function removes intercepts adjustment variables results plotting. filter_sig_OR = TRUE, terms 95% confidence intervals entirely 1 included. Associations colored p-value adjusted p-value, depending user settings. x-axis represents odds ratio () 95% confidence intervals, y-axis shows clinical manifestation predictor variable combinations. name_mapping provided, clinical manifestation predictor names replaced human-readable labels. particularly useful figure preparation publications.

title: Create a Forest Plot of Association Results — make_forest_plot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ forest <- make_forest_plot(   results_df = association_results,   clinical_manifestation = c("arthritis", "nephritis"),   predictor_var_colname = "cluster",   adjust_vars = "Age_dx + sex",   ntop = 10,   adjust_p = TRUE,   pt.size = 2,   y.axis.text.size = 10,   x.axis.text.size = 8,   or.label.size = 3,   plot_title = "Top 10 Cluster Associations",   add_xylabs = TRUE ) print(forest) } # }

what: Run Ranked Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (fGSEA) from limma Results — rank_run_fsgsea
title: Run Ranked Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (fGSEA) from limma Results — rank_run_fsgsea
text: function performs ranked Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) using fgsea based differential expression results (e.g., limma). Genes ranked according log fold change, p-value, combined score, enrichment tested user-specified MSigDB gene set collections. Optionally, enrichment plots summary visualizations top enriched pathways produced.

title: Run Ranked Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (fGSEA) from limma Results — rank_run_fsgsea
code: rank_run_fsgsea(   limma_results_df,   msigdb_collection,   msigdb_cached = NULL,   fgsea_maxsize = 500,   fgsea_minsize = 15,   top_pathways = 10,   rank_by = "logFC+P.Value",   gene_name_colname = "Gene Name",   plot_enrichment = TRUE,   comparison_name = NULL )

title: Run Ranked Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (fGSEA) from limma Results — rank_run_fsgsea
text: limma_results_df data frame containing differential expression results, typically limma::topTable() output. Must include columns logFC, P.Value, gene identifier column. msigdb_collection Character vector specifying one MSigDB collection codes (e.g., "H" hallmark, "C2" curated gene sets). Valid options retrieved via msigdbr::msigdbr_collections(). msigdb_cached Optional pre-fetched MSigDB data frame (avoid repeated API calls). supplied, must contain least columns gs_name, gene_symbol, gs_collection, gs_subcollection, gs_description. fgsea_maxsize Integer; maximum size gene sets include analysis (default: 500). fgsea_minsize Integer; minimum size gene sets include analysis (default: 15). top_pathways Integer; number top enriched pathways display summary plot (default: 10). rank_by Character string specifying genes ranked. Options : "logFC" — rank log fold change. "P.Value" — rank \(-log10(P.Value)\). "logFC+P.Value" — combined ranking using \(-log10(P.Value) * sign(logFC)\) (default). gene_name_colname Character string indicating column name limma_results_df corresponding gene symbols (default: "Gene Name"). plot_enrichment Logical; TRUE, generates enrichment plot top pathway summary plot top enriched pathways (default: TRUE). comparison_name Optional character string used plot titles label comparison (e.g., "Cluster 1 vs Control").

title: Run Ranked Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (fGSEA) from limma Results — rank_run_fsgsea
text: named list containing: ranked_df — Data frame ranked genes scores used enrichment. ranked_genes — Named numeric vector ranked gene scores (input fgsea). gene_set_metadata — Data frame describing gene sets used (name, category, subcategory, description). fgsea_results — Data frame enrichment results fgseaMultilevel(), including NES, p-values, adjusted p-values. fgsea_plot — (Optional) ggplot2 object showing enrichment top pathway. top_pathways_plot — (Optional) ggplot2 object summarizing top enriched pathways.

title: Run Ranked Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (fGSEA) from limma Results — rank_run_fsgsea
text: function first validates chosen MSigDB collections retrieves filters corresponding gene sets. Genes ranked according selected rank_by method, unique gene entries (highest absolute score per gene) retained. ranked gene vector used input fgseaMultilevel() compute enrichment scores (NES) adjusted p-values. Two plots can optionally generated: enrichment curve top pathway. bubble plot summarizing top enriched pathways, bubble color represents adjusted p-value, size represents gene set size, shape indicates significance.

title: Run Ranked Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (fGSEA) from limma Results — rank_run_fsgsea
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example using limma differential expression results gsea_results <- rank_run_fsgsea(   limma_results_df = limma_res,   msigdb_collection = c("H", "C2"),   rank_by = "logFC+P.Value",   comparison_name = "Cluster 1 vs Control" )  # View results and plots head(gsea_results$fgsea_results) gsea_results$top_pathways_plot } # }

what: Run Association Analyses Between Clinical Manifestations (outcome) and a predictor variable (e.g. patient subgroup) — run_associations
title: Run Association Analyses Between Clinical Manifestations (outcome) and a predictor variable (e.g. patient subgroup) — run_associations
text: function performs series (generalized) linear regression models test associations one clinical manifestations categorical predictor variable (e.g., subgroup cluster), optionally adjusting covariates age sex. supports logistic regression (default) returns model objects, ANOVA tables, combined summary odds ratios, confidence intervals, p-values. Optionally, can generate forest plot top associations.

title: Run Association Analyses Between Clinical Manifestations (outcome) and a predictor variable (e.g. patient subgroup) — run_associations
code: run_associations(   clinical_data_df,   clinical_data_cols,   predictor_var_colname = "subgroup",   adjust_by = "Age_dx + male.female_dx",   family = binomial,   link = "logit",   plot = FALSE,   y.axis.text.size = 12,   or.label.size = 3,   ntop = 10,   order = FALSE,   adjust_p = TRUE,   p_adj_method = "BH",   add_xylabs = FALSE,   name_mapping = NULL,   x.axis.text.size = 8,   pt.size = 2,   filter_sig_OR = TRUE,   forest_plot_title = "Associations" )

title: Run Association Analyses Between Clinical Manifestations (outcome) and a predictor variable (e.g. patient subgroup) — run_associations
text: clinical_data_df data frame containing clinical variables (outcomes), predictor variable, optional adjustment covariates. clinical_data_cols Character numeric vector specifying column names indices clinical manifestations (outcome variables) test. predictor_var_colname Character string specifying name predictor variable column (default: "subgroup"). adjust_by Character string defining adjustment variables formula format (e.g., "Age_dx + male.female_dx"). Can include multiple covariates separated "+". family family function regression (default: binomial). link Character string specifying link function (default: "logit"). plot Logical; TRUE, generates forest plot top associations (default: FALSE). y.axis.text.size Numeric; text size y-axis forest plot (default: 12). .label.size Numeric; text size odds ratio labels forest plot (default: 3). ntop Integer; number top associations include forest plot (default: 10). order Logical; TRUE, orders output data frame p-value (default: FALSE). adjust_p Logical; whether perform multiple testing correction (default: TRUE). p_adj_method Character; method p-value adjustment (default: "BH" Benjamini–Hochberg). add_xylabs Logical; whether add x y axis labels forest plot (default: FALSE). name_mapping Optional named vector data frame mapping variable names human-readable labels plot (default: NULL). x.axis.text.size Numeric; text size x-axis forest plot (default: 8). pt.size Numeric; point size forest plot (default: 2). filter_sig_OR Logical; TRUE, filters forest plot show significant associations (based adjusted p-values) (default: TRUE). forest_plot_title Character string; title forest plot (default: "Associations").

title: Run Association Analyses Between Clinical Manifestations (outcome) and a predictor variable (e.g. patient subgroup) — run_associations
text: named list containing: models — Nested list fitted model objects per group outcome. anova — Nested list ANOVA tables model. summarized_results — Combined data frame model estimates, odds ratios, confidence intervals, p-values, (enabled) adjusted p-values. df — Input data frame additional binary indicator columns predictor group. forest_plot — (Optional) ggplot object forest plot top associations.

title: Run Association Analyses Between Clinical Manifestations (outcome) and a predictor variable (e.g. patient subgroup) — run_associations
text: clinical manifestation level predictor variable, function fits model form: $$outcome ~ predictor_level + adjustment_covariates$$ predictor_level binary variable indicating membership given subgroup. Odds ratios, 95% confidence intervals, p-values extracted model. P-values can optionally adjusted multiple testing using specified method.

title: Run Association Analyses Between Clinical Manifestations (outcome) and a predictor variable (e.g. patient subgroup) — run_associations
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ results <- run_associations(   clinical_data_df = lupus_df,   clinical_data_cols = c("nephritis", "arthritis", "rash"),   predictor_var_colname = "cluster",   adjust_by = "Age_dx + sex",   plot = TRUE,   ntop = 15 ) } # }

what: Run UMAP with Custom Parameters — run_custom_umap
title: Run UMAP with Custom Parameters — run_custom_umap
text: function performs Uniform Manifold Approximation Projection (UMAP) input data, allowing customization UMAP parameters, number neighbors, minimum distance, number training epochs.

title: Run UMAP with Custom Parameters — run_custom_umap
code: run_custom_umap(data, neighbors, min_dist, n_epochs = 200)

title: Run UMAP with Custom Parameters — run_custom_umap
text: data matrix dataframe numeric values rows represent samples columns represent features. neighbors integer specifying number neighbors consider point UMAP algorithm. Higher values result capturing broader patterns, lower values capture finer details. min_dist numeric value indicating minimum distance points UMAP embedding. Smaller values keep similar points close, larger values increase separation. n_epochs integer specifying number training epochs UMAP. default value 200. Higher values may improve stability embedding cost computation time.

title: Run UMAP with Custom Parameters — run_custom_umap
text: dataframe two columns (UMAP1, UMAP2) representing UMAP embedding coordinates sample.

title: Run UMAP with Custom Parameters — run_custom_umap
text: function allows flexible UMAP configurations used distance-based input. leverages umap.defaults base overrides specific parameters based function inputs.

title: Run UMAP with Custom Parameters — run_custom_umap
code: # Example usage: # Assuming `data_matrix` is a matrix of distances or a high-dimensional dataset: run_custom_umap(data = data_matrix, neighbors = 15, min_dist = 0.1, n_epochs = 300) #> Error: object 'data_matrix' not found

what: Convert p-value to significance label — signif_label
title: Convert p-value to significance label — signif_label
text: Returns conventional significance label (e.g., "*", "**", "***", "ns") based provided p-value.

title: Convert p-value to significance label — signif_label
code: signif_label(pval)

title: Convert p-value to significance label — signif_label
text: pval numeric p-value.

title: Convert p-value to significance label — signif_label
text: character string representing significance level: "***" p < 0.001 "**" p ≤ 0.01 "*" p ≤ 0.05 "ns" (significant) otherwise

title: Convert p-value to significance label — signif_label
code: signif_label(0.0005)  # returns "***" #> [1] "***" signif_label(0.02)    # returns "*" #> [1] "*" signif_label(0.3)     # returns "ns" #> [1] "ns"

what: Custom ggplot2 theme for subgroups SLE — theme_clustering
title: Custom ggplot2 theme for subgroups SLE — theme_clustering
text: Returns ggplot2 theme object tailored style optimized clustering publication-quality plots. Allows full customization font family, size, color, positioning plot elements.

title: Custom ggplot2 theme for subgroups SLE — theme_clustering
code: theme_clustering(   text_family = "sans",   text_size = 8,   text_color = "black",   plot_title_family = "Lobster Two",   plot_title_size = 20,   plot_title_face = "bold",   plot_title_color = "#2a475e",   axis_title_size = 12,   axis_text_size = 10,   axis_text_color = "black",   caption_text_color = "black",   caption_text_size = 8,   caption_face_style = "bold",   legend_text_size = 12,   legend_text_color = "black",   legend_title_face_style = "bold",   legend_position = "top" )

title: Custom ggplot2 theme for subgroups SLE — theme_clustering
text: text_family Font family general plot text. text_size Base text size. text_color Color general plot text. plot_title_family Font family plot title. plot_title_size Font size plot title. plot_title_face Font face plot title (e.g., "bold", "italic"). plot_title_color Color plot title. axis_title_size Font size axis titles. axis_text_size Font size axis tick labels. axis_text_color Color axis tick labels. caption_text_color Color caption text. caption_text_size Size caption text. caption_face_style Face style caption text (e.g., "bold"). legend_text_size Font size legend text. legend_text_color Color legend text. legend_title_face_style Face style legend title (e.g., "bold"). legend_position Position legend (e.g., "top", "bottom", "none").

title: Custom ggplot2 theme for subgroups SLE — theme_clustering
text: ggplot2 theme object added plot.

title: Custom ggplot2 theme for subgroups SLE — theme_clustering
code: library(ggplot2) ggplot(antibody_dataset, aes(x = Subgroup, y = `HLA PRS 4 SNP`)) +   geom_boxplot() +   theme_clustering() #> Error: object 'antibody_dataset' not found

what: Transform Autoantibody Data for Line Plot — transform_data_for_line_plot
title: Transform Autoantibody Data for Line Plot — transform_data_for_line_plot
text: Prepares long-format data frame showing percentage frequency positive autoantibody results per subgroup, suitable plotting ggplot2.

title: Transform Autoantibody Data for Line Plot — transform_data_for_line_plot
code: transform_data_for_line_plot(   df,   autoantibody_columns,   subgroup_column = "Clustering" )

title: Transform Autoantibody Data for Line Plot — transform_data_for_line_plot
text: df data frame containing autoantibody data subgroup information. autoantibody_columns character vector column names integer vector column positions corresponding autoantibody variables include. subgroup_column character string integer indicating subgroup column group . Defaults "Clustering".

title: Transform Autoantibody Data for Line Plot — transform_data_for_line_plot
text: long-format data frame following columns: Subgroup column grouping variable (e.g., Clustering). Autoantibody name autoantibody. Frequency percentage positive results within subgroup.

title: Transform Autoantibody Data for Line Plot — transform_data_for_line_plot
text: function: Extracts specified autoantibody columns subgroup column. Converts autoantibody binary values numeric (needed). Calculates sum positives per subgroup. Divides subgroup size obtain percentage positivity. Returns data melted long format suitable plotting.

title: Transform Autoantibody Data for Line Plot — transform_data_for_line_plot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example usage df <- your_data_frame autoantibody_vars <- c("anti-dsDNA", "anti-Sm", "anti-RNP") freq_long <- transform_data_for_line_plot(df, autoantibody_columns = autoantibody_vars)  library(ggplot2) ggplot(freq_long, aes(x = Autoantibody, y = Frequency, group = Clustering, color = Clustering)) +   geom_line() + geom_point() } # }

what: Create a stylized violin plot with jittered points and boxplots — violin_plot_ggstats_style
title: Create a stylized violin plot with jittered points and boxplots — violin_plot_ggstats_style
text: function creates violin plot overlaid jittered data points boxplot, using consistent visual style suitable statistical reporting. also supports custom axis labels, titles, captions, color palettes.

title: Create a stylized violin plot with jittered points and boxplots — violin_plot_ggstats_style
code: violin_plot_ggstats_style(   data,   x,   y,   xlab = NULL,   ylab = NULL,   caption = NULL,   title = NULL,   subtitle = NULL,   point.args = list(position = ggplot2::position_jitterdodge(dodge.width = 0.6), alpha =     0.4, size = 3, stroke = 0, na.rm = TRUE),   boxplot.args = list(width = 0.3, alpha = 0.2, na.rm = TRUE),   violin.args = list(width = 0.5, alpha = 0.2, na.rm = TRUE),   color_values = NULL )

title: Create a stylized violin plot with jittered points and boxplots — violin_plot_ggstats_style
text: data data frame containing variables plotted. x categorical variable (unquoted) used x-axis. y numeric variable (unquoted) used y-axis. xlab Optional custom label x-axis. Defaults variable name. ylab Optional custom label y-axis. Defaults variable name. caption Optional caption displayed bottom plot. title Optional main title plot. subtitle Optional subtitle plot. point.args list arguments passed geom_point() control jittered point appearance. boxplot.args list arguments passed geom_boxplot() control boxplot appearance. violin.args list arguments passed geom_violin() control violin plot appearance. color_values Optional named vector colors used manually set fill point colors (e.g., c("Group1" = "blue", "Group2" = "red")).

title: Create a stylized violin plot with jittered points and boxplots — violin_plot_ggstats_style
text: ggplot object representing combined violin-box-jitter plot.

title: Create a stylized violin plot with jittered points and boxplots — violin_plot_ggstats_style
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{   library(ggplot2)   violin_plot_ggstats_style(antibody_dataset, y = `HLA PRS 4 SNP`, x = Subgroup,                              xlab = "HLA PRS", ylab = "Subgroups",                              title = "Distribution of HLA PRA across subgroups",                              color_values = acr_subgroups_paper_colors()) } # }

what: Visualize Clustering Results with t-SNE and UMAP — visualize_clusters
title: Visualize Clustering Results with t-SNE and UMAP — visualize_clusters
text: Visualizes cluster assignments PAM model using t-SNE UMAP dimensionality reduction techniques. UMAP computed several combinations n_neighbors min_dist values. function returns plots optionally saves .

title: Visualize Clustering Results with t-SNE and UMAP — visualize_clusters
code: visualize_clusters(   x,   pam_fit,   df,   id_col,   umap_nneight = c(10L, 15L, 20L, 25L, 30L, 35L, 40L, 45L, 50L),   umap_min_dist = c(0.1, 0.25, 0.3, 0.5, 0.75, 0.99),   point_size = 2,   stability_col = "stability",   save_plots = FALSE,   plot_outpath = "." )

title: Visualize Clustering Results with t-SNE and UMAP — visualize_clusters
text: x dissimilarity matrix (must class "dissimilarity"). pam_fit fitted PAM object (e.g., cluster::pam()). df Data frame containing metadata including IDs stability scores. id_col Character. Name ID column df. umap_nneight Integer vector. Values UMAP n_neighbors parameter. umap_min_dist Numeric vector. Values UMAP min_dist parameter. point_size Numeric. Size points plots. Default 2. stability_col Character. Column name df stores cluster stability metrics. save_plots Logical. TRUE, plots saved plot_outpath. plot_outpath Character. Directory path saving plots. Default current directory.

title: Visualize Clustering Results with t-SNE and UMAP — visualize_clusters
text: list : tsne_plot ggplot2 object visualizing clusters via t-SNE. umap_plots nested list ggplot2 UMAP plots indexed neighbor distance parameters.
